title: REALLY SAD BEHAVIOUR
body: I was in a game playing Tristana and I accidentally fed, and I started getting kills then these people started calling me names and being rude. At first I stayed calm, after that I got really angry so I just muted them, then after couple minutes un muted them and they were still being rude and cruel to me. I did accidentally steal some kills but most of the kills I got were mine. I also have video footage, from LoLReplay. I can send you some footage but I might upload some really bad parts to YouTube. A lot of people die each year from this sort of stuff, just sending you this so you can posting this so you guys can be aware of how much this little chat can affect someones life.

I've had incidents like this happen quite a few times.

I usually forward the information to Riot support, but each time I get a support representative telling me to let the Tribunal do it's work... Does Riot support know that we don't have the Tribunal yet?

There's a really big difference between people just being mean/rude, and people going as far as to describe how you should kill yourself, who finds you, etc.

One of my friends that I play with often was abused a few weeks ago. He had someone tell him how much he hoped his mother died, and when my friend pointed out that his mother was already dead, the disgusting level of abuse just increased. This isn't content that should even be shown at the LoL Tribunal (when we get it), but to the Australian police..

Ahh that's interesting I will get in touch with the support team to adjust their messaging. Really sorry you went through/experienced some negative games. We are working hard to  improve online behavior but it is a tough endeavor!

Right now we have multiple automatic systems in place to punish negative behaviour; for example

Live

LeaverBuster
Chat restrictions
Intentional feeder bans
Manual audits

Currently testing

Automatic verbal abuse bans

This is of course just the negative stuff, we are also working on ways to promote and recognize positive play within our community as well!
http://oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/special-event/celebrating-end-years-snowdown

Our player behavior philosophies include punishment, reform, and positive reinforcement. There's no silver bullet to improving player behavior in online games, and you always need a mix of punishments and rewards. You can read more about our design philosophies here: http://oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/player-behavior/exploring-player-behavior-design-values

If you're really interested in player behaviour give this video a watch it is Jeffrey "Lyte" Lin talking about "The Science Behind Shaping Player Behavior in Online Games".
http://gdcvault.com/play/1017940/The-Science-Behind-Shaping-Player
I saw you post that video a while ago. Its really good stuff.

Yeah! it definitely changed the way I looked at the problem, it's not a small population of toxic players that just needs to be banned. Its a large population of **neutral/positive** players that have a bad day once in a while (sometimes multiple people have a bad day in the same game).

> [{quoted}](name=Maraudaur,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=YlGN1v4T,comment-id=000b0000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-03T08:37:12.521+0000)
>
> Yeah! it definitely changed the way I looked at the problem, it's not a small population of toxic players that just needs to be banned. Its a large population of **neutral/positive** players that have a bad day once in a while (sometimes multiple people have a bad day in the same game).

I think like too many people can look at it like "Why is this toxic person not banned?" when the person in question is, overall, not a very toxic person. From what they witness though, and it is often the only time they will see that player, that player is a highly angry and abusive player. That's the problem. Obviously though, you can't just tell a player to dismiss it and say "Its probably the only time they will do this", because people can become repeat offenders and if there is no threat of punishment they will feel like its something they can repeat and get away with.
A group in the playerbase will say "Just ban these people", but the problem is that means a lot of generally good people will be forced from the game. Like Lyte says though, you guys at Riot think it can be possible to help modify and shape your players' behaviours. I think that is an admirable goal which says a lot about the company.

While I understand where you're coming from, yes these insults are actually decently mild in the grand scheme of things, it shouldn't be ignored just because most people can ignore that. There are some, whether by their own faults or by a flawed psychological state imposed upon them by external factors, who don't have the mental capacity to handle things like this. And I'm not talking about the people who do these things for attention, but the people with legitimate issues. Just because the majority knows to ignore these things doesn't mean that the minority should be ignored, because there's a very real chance that these trolls will one day say something like this to the wrong person and directly contribute to someone injuring themselves.

Is it a stupid practice, and are the people who participate in it, whether legitimate mental issues or simply filling a stereotypical role stupid for hurting themselves? Of course. But they don't need encouragement from other human beings who can't differentiate between their actions online creating consequences offline. Yes they're failed trolls, and yes they should be ignored. But that doesn't alter in any way that they're treating someone else as less than human over a damned game. 

Letting behavior like this go unpunished at the tip of the iceberg is what allows the other 90% below the surface to become so large.
